title: Will there be an initial public offering on either the Shanghai Stock Exchange or the Shenzhen Stock Exchange before 1 January 2016?

Dropping probability by 25% and watching closely to see whether this is an anomaly or beginning of a rout. Down 5.48% so far today.

Better late than never: At what point is an IPO considered to be "on the market" (for this IFP)?  When traded freely on the given stock market after listing? or when the shares become available for bid or purchase?

Chinese Stocks Fall on Restart of IPOs
Chairman of large brokerage AWOL for past week.

10 companies have green light to restart IPO process.

From the link
China’s securities watchdog said last week it will allow 28 IPOs by year-end and let the market to play a bigger role in the supply and pricing of new listings.
An uptick in U.S. inflation, released Tuesday, is the latest signal supporting expectations that the Fed will raise short-term interest rates next month.

Among the 28 IPOs that were suspended in July because of sharp market falls, ten companies were given the approval to restart their initial public offerings (IPO) Friday, according to Deng Ge, spokesman with the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC).

The Bloomberg link below from yesterday sats the Bank of China has injected liquidity into the system in preparation for anticipated IPO's.  They neglected to do this the last time and apparently gummed up the works.

A third regulatory official involved in China’s initial public offerings has been arrested
http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1a6146dc-8e82-11e5-8be4-3506bf20cc2b.html
"China Shares Fall as Chances of IPO Flurry Nears"  [1]

One suspects that the gummint would like at least a couple of IPOs in order to show that faith has been restored; appearances are quite important to the Party (luckily this is not true anywhere else...).  The IPOs don't have to be successful to be counted, I don't suppose. They could even be withdrawn, although I'll bet the gummint would stump up some cash rather than permit this.

Ugh - now I'm doubting my own analysis. I still wonder who the buyers will be, though I guess it could be the government. They have seem to want to normalize markets and provide funding to these companies. A successful IPO would provide the confidence that they want the market to have.

Upping this since I just read the lifting of the ban. Doesn't negate the fact that IPO's usually don't happen during a market adjustment like this. While the companies need financing, market conditions would usually make it too unattractive to do so. China's not a normal market though and anyway, how should one think about "equity" and ownership in companies of a communist country. A shareholder doesn't "own" a share of the company in any real sense of the word.
IPO's are rare when markets crash, though it has recovered somewhat. It could happen, but risk appetite is still low there, I think.
Thanks to Xu, I'll jump in strong:) Thanks for the link!!
You have about a week to get on board; this has to happen.  Moved from 91% (when it was lonely) to 98% where is now crowded.
Per Xu, I guess so. I would be at 90-95% to account for the possiblity of delay, but I've been pretty low in this already, so up it goes.
Jumping in at 100% thanks to the link from Xu --> http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/42768

Only just saw the news for this even though it happened a week ago. And its not really an active question here either. 
"Ten of the 28 companies that were in the process of listing when the freeze began will restart the process after Nov. 20, said another CSRC official at the same briefing, who asked not to be identified because of agency rules. It will take two weeks for the 10 to complete the process, while the remaining 18 will sell shares by the end of the year, Deng said."
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-09/china-to-resume-ipos-by-year-end-as-stocks-enter-bull-market
This question should be closing around the beginning of December then.
Forgot to account for the lifting of the embargo.  That makes it kind of likely.

The CSRC has removed its embargo on IPO, which paves the way for listings.  However, they will still need to go through the approval process. It is likely that at least some will list prior to Chinese New Year, but that doesn't imply it would be before our New Year.  Many companies will have been on track to IPO though, so lead time for IPOing this companies may be short.

This looks like it is going to happen.  Interesting move by the central committee, but will likely be supported in the shadows with the government buying up shares to make them successful and continue the illusion that is China.

The CSRC further detailed that 10 of the 28 firms that were granted with regulatory approval for new share sales are set to launch their respective IPOs after Nov. 20.
http://en.yibada.com/articles/82367/20151107/ipos-resume-market-slide-china-s-securities-regulator.htm

Forecast per the Nov. 20 date, and assuming the year end reference is not the Chinese New Year.

I was way wrong on this one!

Increasing odds after reports the government will lift sanctions: https://www.gjopen.com/questions/4-will-there-be-an-initial-public-offering-on-either-the-shanghai-stock-exchange-or-the-shenzhen-stock-exchange-before-1-january-2016

Reuters updated:
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/06/china-ipo-idUSL3N1313NV20151106
"The CSRC said that 28 companies which had seen their already-approved listings halted by the freeze would be the first out of the gate, adding they have two weeks to prepare for the resumption, with the first batch of 10 companies launching after November 20."

http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/06/china-ipo-idUSL3N1313NV20151106
China's securities regulator said on Friday it would allow the resumption of initial public offerings in China, lifting a suspension put into effect in July as regulators desperately tried to slow a devastating stock market crash.
...
The CSRC said that 28 companies which had seen their already-approved listings halted by the freeze would be the first out of the gate, adding they have two weeks to prepare for the resumption.
The announcement comes after signs Chinese stock markets have finally stabilised; this week the CSI300 index posted its best weekly performance since June with rising transaction volumes.

"The IPO suspension will end, as it has each time the government has imposed such a moratorium, although if precedent is anything to go by the last time the government intervened to suspend IPOs was in November 2012; the ban lasted 14 months and was never properly explained by the regulator. The shortest suspension lasted three months in 2001."  [1]

SSEA @ 3622
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-08-16/china-analysts-see-ipo-resumption-by-year-end-as-stocks-recover
August article estimated IPO's would resume with SSEA around 4500, as brokers pledged not to sell holdings below that level. Not sure if this info is still accurate.
Investigation of CSRC is still ongoing following stock market crash earlier this year.
Following shanghaitrader, and noting that the timeframe is getting short.

Ratcheting this down further.  The Chinese government has picked up its purging of the investment community domestically and I think that places a greater tilt to this question.  When you examine those that have been purged, it has been the risk takers and that does not bode well for things like IPOs this year.
As before, shanghaitrader should know ... -1. (What a killjoy you are!)

the central anti-corruption bureau has started an onsite check-up at the Chinese SEC, and this recent operation involves a dozen of other institutions, too, including the PBOC and Chinese Forex Bureau. According to the news, the inspection teams will stay for two months in these institutions. Within the two months, I susptect all the staff in Chinese SEC would be busy digging out/sorting their archieves, deleting their phone messages and call list, answering all sorts of  questions, and writing lengthy detailed reports for pretty much everything. This has the same effect of putting them on holiday for two months, because nobody would be really working on anything, So, I think the chance of a change of policy is zero now.

"Chinese investors [hold] $22 trillion of investable assets"

http://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-cicc-prices-hong-kong-ipo-at-top-of-range-1446290476

I continue to think China will allow an IPO this year to match Xi's message of free markets, even if this message has been plagued with some contradictions. After all, the yuan is being seriously considered as a second global reserve currency.
A company which has to IPO will IPO.

Foxconn to list IPO on Chinese exchange! 
[... within three to five years.]
http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news/content?id=20150628000003&cid=1206
Too late in the year to offer an IPO. Till markets don't stabilise for a period of at least 6 months it will not happen
Suspended, but it will be difficult to stop the flow for long.

The strength of other markets to publicly raise money makes Chinese markets less attractive because there is a lack of trust against Chinese government by the public (even its own people). China needs a littlev more time to prove itself and win the market's trust before an IPO launch.
These exchanges see themselves as separate and unique, thus will act on market info unrelated to the us or European markets.

Going from 12->10%. Chinese easing announced yesterday...RRR decline and rate cut in tandem...reinforce that Chinese govt still quite concerned about weakness in economy, and growth below its internal targets. From the government's perspective, IPOs are only permissible during more economically stable times. IPO window will reopen when Chinese economy declines at a rate the govt is comfortable with.

-2 on planned reverse IPO.
"We've been planning this for many years" said an executive.
Why do I not believe him?
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/23/china-logistics-idUSL3N12N24K20151023

One of the main purposes of the gov trying to prop up the market a year ago was to create enough enthusiasm so that the naive public would rush in and provide capital for all the toxi garbage of state owned banks and corporations - most of which were on the top of the approved IPO list. Now with the initiation of new Chinese version of QE, most banks and hence state owned companies don't have an urgent need to suck capital from the equity market anymore.  And hence, I decrease my forecast to 5%.
Prediction based on historical IPO suspension

Chinese public continues to be excluded from privatization of public assets
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/18/bank-of-china-ipo-idUSL3N12I05220151018

"shares of companies that went public with disappointing IPO prices in September are currently providing positive returns"
http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory/data-years-biggest-ipo-prices-estimates-34495304

From 30 to 25%
"When one state-backed Chinese company invests in another, getting the best available return on investment may not be the only consideration."
There are still so many assets to privatize, but it's such a mess.
http://blogs.reuters.com/breakingviews/2015/10/15/hong-kong-ipos-leaning-too-heavily-on-cornerstones/

I was staying away from this one for quite awhile because I don't see any economic reason for a company to list, but the political situation could have a strong impact on this.  Oddly enough, there is a small article today in the Wall Street Journal about a Chinese company that makes sex toys looking to list.  This could be a great trial balloon for the Chinese market with a company that is not likely to raise a great deal either way and would not be seen as an indicator of anything bad if it didn't go well.  No timeframes were given, but giving this even odds to happen at this point.
http://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2015/10/14/the-next-hot-chinese-listing-a-sex-toy-maker/
It seems that most of the crowd is leaning on the opinions of a few.  I'm growing uncomfortable with such a strong forecast on an issue I don't understand, so I'm moving from the crowd to 35%

If their markets were stable right now, I believe we would see a number of public offerings. However, I believe China will be happy just to have their markets stable for a few months. Wait until the first or second quarter of next year to see a flurry of IPOs

Reducing 15 to 12%. Time running out. Economic numbers still bad. China could care less about foreign opinions to "restore confidence", which are touted by the higher-probability guessers below. China cares about stabilizing the market. IPOs are seen as sucking liquidity out of the market. They're permitted when the market is strong, not weak.

Escalating tensions in China's financial system
"Hebei Financing defaulted on us, and we defaulted on our clients"
http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/banking-finance/chinese-investor-stabs-asset-management-ceo-after-default
from 52 to 32%
I don't believe so. Although that would signal to the world China's markets are now stable, since they aren't I don't believe China wants more egg on their face
China is trying to restore confidence in its markets after the massive interventions in late summer. So I think they will permit IPOs before year-end.
See redacted article.  Not sure about timeframe. Will monitor.

Chinese central bank governor: China's stock market correction is "almost over." 
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/china-business/11925819/Asian-markets-rally-as-China-says-stock-market-correction-almost-over.html

the mkt plunges every time after the IPO suspention was lifted, so the politically correct decision for the Chinese SEC to make is to not further ruin the vunerable mkt, which is currently far from having stablized/bottomed. the reason i assign a probability higher than 10% is that there's been increasing political instability in China this year, and the major government departments have started making obviously stupid decisions, which beneath the surface is to benifit certain interest groups who are in for a short-term profit. Even the official stock market rescue was recently reported to have been completely taken advantage of by front-running and insider trading. so I wouldn't be too surprised to learn that those big firms with huge/collapsing debt burden bribed the Chinese SEC enough that the SEC decided to re-initiate IPOs, disregarding the general market sentiment, the risk of losing office, and the sure outcome of being blamed by the media.

"China Dream" turns into Nightmare.
Obscure "State Backed" Commodities Exchange Balks at Redemptions
"It is unusual though for investors to protest in Beijing and Shanghai in front of government offices, such as the securities regulator - the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC)."
http://investmentguruindia.com/StockMarket/rare-metals-investment-blow-up-shows-risks-lurking-in-chinas-financial-system
China Analysts See IPO Resuming by Year-End as Stocks Climb. Backlog of companies waiting to raise capital
Markets have recovered though regulators are likely to remain cagey. Also, looks like people are just listing in Hong Kong.

Given the depressed state of the markets plus high volatility it's hard to see the IPO freeze being lifted in the immediate future. In addition the question is "Will there be an initial public offering" and not "Will the initial public offering freeze be lifted" so the IPO would have to actually take place by 1 January so the clock is running down very quickly.
Economic situation inside occupied China far worse than the dictatorship is letting on.

It is important to realize that the question isn't: "Will the IPO suspension be lift?"  This is important b/c since the suspension, the market is down BIG, which means that far fewer companies will actually want to IPO right now.  Also, w/ 3 months remaining till this question time runs out, there will be a delay between the time the ban is lifted and when the IPO actually launches trading.  I've never been an i-banker, but just as a rough estimate given my limited research time available, I figure it'd take around a month from the time a ban is lifted to the time when the first IPO is actually launched.  So I'm realistically asking if the ban will be lifted in the next 2 months.  China likes to exert control, and I think they really think their logically control can get the markets to do what they want--look at their behavior w/r/t the renminbi.  So I think they dont lift the ban in the next two months b/c the markets are still in the doldrums.

Staying put with sse trading 3053.  Relying on @gjdrew bloomberg article. For ease of reference http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-08-16/china-analysts-see-ipo-resumption-by-year-end-as-stocks-recover

CSRC ready to pull the trigger for IPOs
"601 companies have submitted applications to the CSRC and are on a waiting list for new offerings on the mainland"
http://www.scmp.com/business/china-business/article/1863293/csrc-ready-pull-trigger-ipos

No news is bad news where the monetization of hype and promotion is concerned.
∴ going from 40 to 35%
Such action as there is seems to have moved to HongKong and elsewhere for the near term.
Stabilization of the Chinese market would have to occur before the authoritarian regime will allow IPOs to be offered on it's markets.
China's problems have only just begun.  This will not be an environment for and IPO
The Chinese markets need to stabilize before the gov't will allow more IPOs.  Brace for more global volatility from here to the end of the year.

Still think no. things are calming down, but I think china would like to see an extended period of calm (at least a coupe of months) before allowing riskier operations such as IPOs. Also, a lot of what we're seeing now is due to heavy gov't intervention in markets. IPOs much harder to control.
The chinese gov needs to show a positive sign before the end of the year.
A rebound in the stock market and the drive of the government to show that the bear market has ended may initiate some IPOs.
An IPO could be made any time, but right now economic conditions would not favour one.

China market will need recover from current bear market, the pending decision of US rate hike and very weak China economy will take 3 years or longer to recover, it's too early to have IPO on both exchanges before 1/1/2016
very difficult times, but the government may be happy to see some new IPOs as demonstration that the stock market crisis has ended.
Market is too nervous at the moment to have any successful IPO

"further IPOs unlikely on Chinese exchanges this year"
http://www.finchannel.com/index.php/business/item/49332-global-ipo-activity-hit-as-volatility-spikes-and-china-pauses
âˆ´ 45% -> 40%
I should follow the crowd on this because I have no background/expertise in this area.

Well, if there's a perfect IPO candidate, here it is:
"The move will be in line with Beijing's plans to allow domestic private investors greater access to its energy sector."
http://in.reuters.com/article/2015/09/24/china-oil-soereform-idINL4N11T56320150924
Is anybody in China now looking for an IPO to put money into?

Hong Kong taking big Chinese IPOs, and other candidates getting private equity. There seems to be quite a bit of cash still "floating" around, so the Chinese market officials have got to be getting tempted to re-open the IPOs.
Not good timing but government may want to send a signal still open for business?
Following other forecasters. No positive news on this front, and timeframe arguments seem valid.

There have been nine IPO suspensions since 1990; all longer than 3,5 months. All these occasions were not as bad as the recent.

this is only 3 1/2 months away.  It takes months to prepare an IPO, and many stocks are still closed.   China won't even consider allowing IPOs until all the stocks are allowed to trade, and have done so for a while.
Based on rationale analysis of forecasters I'm following.
Not a good time for an IPO on a Chinese exchange; things are too weird. Probably not before at least Spring '16.
Won't happen so soon, it's not a good time. They'll  wait till everything settles.

While the market continues to decline, no. But once the froth is cleared away there does seem to be an abundant  supply of government owned entities that they want to privatize. They might drop some of these in an attempt to influence the market. They shouldn't, but they also shouldn't have made those previous panic moves at influencing the market either. As @slobodan says, it might be more of a political call to place an IPO that holds its price as a sign of market stability.

No. This is really a shorter time than it appears at first. From Thanksgiving on is slow for US, European financials, so not then because they will want all the foreign support they can get. January is slow fro Chinese financials (learned this one forecasting iron ore prices last year!), so not then. So will they authorize IPOs prior to mid-November? Probably not, it's just been too crazy.
Not  a good time for a business to raise capital
Things need to settle down first.

the forecasters I'm following say 33%
the forecasts I've up voted average 30%
So, I'm moving downward a smidgen

China is not a conventional market. Government has substantial sway and stakes. It may be a good ploy to launch:
a. A popular IPO (a state-firm, for instance) that will raise interest
b. In case interest is not generated by the masses, the government will do a buy back to ensure success. 
Downside risks are less (I could go with a 30% chance on this).
Too soon.  Maybe by 1 September 2016.  The shocks from this summer scared the leaders.
No end to market turmoil for now. 6 months is fairly short compared to previous IPO halts.
China suspended initial public offerings, in an effort to shore up its stock market, which has had the largest three-week drop since 1992.

Suspension has been in place since July, so it is likely to continue for awhile--at least until the current crisis has been mitigated. On the other hand, these things seldom go one for a really long time.

sve je stvar politike a ne ekonomije     
everything is a matter of politics, not economics

Stabilization is the main concern for the Chinese government especially when they've lost some credibility for their handling of the previous market turmoil. I don't think the Chinese government is ready to let the market go loose in the short term especially given recent signals that tighten control of the stock market, such as limiting the hedging ability by putting a ceiling of 100 futures contracts per market participant.
Markets appear to have stabilized after a summer of selling. A new IPO would be a bullish sign for global markets and Chinese investors-- something that has been in short supply of late

Given recent volatility and falling confidence in the market and economy, the short timeline on this question makes it odds against finding in favor of this proposition.

China unlikely to want to increase supply of shares at present, in order to prevent dilution to stock market returns, and also to avoid introducing extra event risk (regulatory). If Fed were to raise funds rate materially (25bps) that could argue in favour of a need to compete for capital with more issuance. But prices in US, as measured by realtime trackers, are rolling over, and in current volatility a 15bp or no raise seems more likely.  Even if China does reapprove IPO's, one has to get to market in this timeframe, despite inevitably higher regulatory scrutiny levels.

Yes, "More Info" links indicate the primary reason for discontinuing the IPO's is to prevent them from diverting new funds from existing stock issues (one effort intended to prop up the falling prices).  Although the links do not specificly identify a government mandate, 28 IPO's were suspended: 18 on Shenzen and 10 on Shanghi.

It's believed Beijing has targeted Shanghai reaching 4500 as the stability trigger for IPOs. It's no where near this. 3155.04 as of a few days ago. (h/t for link to GJDrew)  http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-08-16/china-analysts-see-ipo-resumption-by-year-end-as-stocks-recover PRC isn't ready for the hurly burly of IPO, at least not until their market numbers stabilise. Probably not this year.

The last IPO freeze in China lasted 15 months and only ended in December 2013 [1].  An average 15-month freeze suggests a 23% estimate. Given that conditions in China now are are worse than they were then, a longer freeze might be expected.
So no IPO's for 7 months?  I'll take the under.
